Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Gabriel García Márquez's biography and memoirs, particularly "Living to Tell the Tale." Here's what I discovered:

## Gabriel García Márquez's Biographical Works and Memoirs

García Márquez wrote his memoir "Vivir para contarla" (Living to Tell the Tale) in 2002, after being diagnosed with cancer in 1999. "Living to Tell the Tale" is the first volume of García Márquez's planned three-volume autobiography, originally published in Spanish in 2002, with an English translation by Edith Grossman published in 2003.

### About "Living to Tell the Tale"

The memoir tells the story of García Márquez's life from 1927 through 1950, ending with his proposal to his wife. It focuses heavily on García Márquez's family, schooling, and early career as a journalist and short story writer, and includes references to numerous real-life events that ended up in his novels.

García Márquez explained in many interviews and in his autobiography that he grew up in the midst of ghosts and fantastic tales, since his grandmother was an accomplished storyteller.

### Cancer Diagnosis and Motivation to Write

The cancer diagnosis prompted García Márquez to begin writing his memoirs, as he told El Tiempo: "I reduced relations with my friends to a minimum, disconnected the telephone, canceled the trips and all sorts of current and future plans, and locked myself in to write every day without interruption".

The book's title "Living to Tell the Tale" gains greater significance because García Márquez had been fighting lymphatic cancer since 1999.

### Authorized Biographies

The search results reveal information about authorized biographical works:

Gerald Martin wrote an authorized biography that "offers a total immersion into the author's life and career". This biography "unearthed facts never before presented to the reading public" and tracked "the evolution of a small-town boy from the steamy Caribbean region of Colombia into a novelist".

### Family Context and Interviews

García Márquez's son Rodrigo García wrote "A farewell to Gabo and Mercedes: A son's memoir of Gabriel García Márquez and Mercedes Barcha" published by Harper Collins in 2021.

Regarding interviews throughout his career, García Márquez said: "An immense majority of the ones I have not been able to avoid on any subject ought to be considered as an important part of my works of fiction, because they are no more than that: fantasies about my life".

### Later Years and Legacy

Gabriel García Márquez died at home in Mexico City at the age of 87 after living with dementia for over 10 years. In his memoir he wrote, "Life is not what one lived, but what one remembers and how one remembers it in order to recount it," but in his final years he could no longer recall anything.

The memoir stands as a significant autobiographical work that provides insight into the formative experiences that shaped one of Latin America's greatest writers.
